title: Wednesday, 28th March, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:07 am

Here's what we wrote on Monday .....

(Apologies for @Flaneur in the middle of that. Apologies also for Flaneur more generally.)

(@Arash: Thumbs up )

Miss Piggy 'tis but a scratch on the FTSE100, still a down day for the index.

Typo Shire contributing 17 to the FTSE

So ..... Has the Panel bounced Takeda into a statement? It hasn't put in an approach yet, it's only thinking about it.

BE11:12am

https://www.invest...1803281023142333J/

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Takeda's consideration of such an offer is at a preliminary and exploratory stage and no approach has been made to the Board of Shire. There can be no certainty that an approach, if made, will lead to any transaction.

Flaneur :)
Miss Piggy Shire is only 1.75% of FTSE100 weight
VV75 I'm positive it was the panel
BE11:13am

It does, however, offer a bunch of bullet points on why this makes sense.

BE11:13am

· strengthen Takeda's core therapeutic areas of oncology, GI and neuroscience

· accelerate Takeda's vision to be a leader in specialized medicines that are transformative to patients through the addition of Shire's leading global rare disease franchise

· further enhance Takeda's robust R&D strategy, concentrating on key therapeutic areas

· reinforce a strong and large-molecule focused late-stage pipeline within Takeda's core therapeutic areas to complement Takeda's own pipeline and discovery capabilities

· balance Takeda's geographic focus to align with the market opportunity in the U.S.

· drive financial value from a strong combined financial profile

11:13 am
BE11:14am

.... because this'd be gigantic for Takeda. I don't think anyone's talked in the past about it going .... what, $60bn EV?

LJ morning
Otter Hello friendos
Philruffin any news on zurn?
BE11:15am

The question follows is whether this bounces another party into moving. We talked a lot about Pfizer last year, of course, and also the possibility of Abbvie rekindling its interest.

Arash Massoudi, FT @BE i can confirm Panel bounced Takeda
GBKrona Takeda making hay whilst the QE sun shines and interest rates still low?
GBKrona well done @BE for outing them
BE11:16am

There's an obvious forex angle here too. Shire was, going into today, about 50% cheaper in dollar terms than when Abbvie was trying to buy it. Picture pretty similar in yen.

Typo Well, 20% of 1.75% is...?
GBKrona so minimum price £45?
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Anyway, clearly this is breaking too late for us to have any real analysis. What we can do is chuck up some historic stuff saying Shire's undervalued assuming it's not going to breach banking covenants.

Pharma Hasn't the tax position changed for US companies making overseas takeovers? Tax arbitrage seemed to be the primary motivation at the time.
MnM The might just get me above water on Shire
Lemmy ...but the tax inversion attraction has waned, cf Pfizer/Allergan
BE11:18am

Which relies largely on its haemophilia revenue not disappearing, which we can talk about a bit later.

BE11:18am

Here's SocGen from a couple of weeks ago.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Downgrades to forecasts have been exacerbated by de-rating.
In our view this can be restored by the following: 1) rising confidence in the sustainability of the haemophilia and HAE (severe facial swelling) franchises, 2) an exit from its cash-generative neuroscience unit, and/or 3) on upside surprises from Xiidra (eye care). We know Roche’s Hemilibra is still a bugbear. But the independent haemophilia expert we consulted does not believe this drug will be disruptive because this market is very “sticky”. Hence, we see Shire’s guidance of a 30% reduction in its non-inhibitor sales by 2020 as too cautious. Indeed, we think Sanofi would agree, having recently paid 20x 2018e P/E for Bioverativ, a pure haemophilia play. In 2H18 we expect the HAE focus will shift to SHP643’s greater convenience and a rising tide of treatment rates. A sale of neuroscience (ADHD) would also be a catalyst as it would turbo-boost deleveraging. But in our view, a simple spin-off would also be good as it removes the negative EPS growth from the Vyvanse patent expiry. We think ex-ADHD it can repay all its debt as other franchises are highly sustainable.

BE11:19am

Shire is poorly valued on consensus estimates due to concerns that its haemophilia and HAE franchises are not sustainable and that it cannot service its debts without ADHD. We strongly disagree. Our TP of £75 is an average of 2018-20e EV/EBITA multiples (£64) and DCF (£86). Applying the 20x P/E Sanofi paid for Bioverativ would value Shire’s haemophilia business at £20/share. We continue to value ADHD at £10/share. Subtracting this £30 from the current share price implies that the remaining franchises (which account for nearly 50% of group EPS and are all durable, in our view) trade on a low-single-digit 2018e P/E – hardly rational.

BE11:20am

(@Pharma: true. Shire's changed too. It's now a value play on haemo protection and a pipeline of potentials, like SHP643 and SHP647, rather than a tax avoidance mechanism.)

Romeike Minimum price £52
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Interesting that you're struggling to find any analyst who's negative on Shire. Zero sells according to my data.

GBKrona MnM - from your keyboard to Takeda's ears...
BE11:22am

Citi's highly rated pharma team also buyers.

BE11:23am

Our forecasts encompass a robust growth outlook for Immunology (20% of FY17 sales) and new product launches, hemophillia (25% of sales) headwinds, and risks around further Fosrenol/Lialda/Pentasa generics (6% of sales). We also see pipeline potential that the market seems to ignore. This drives a 2018-23e sales/EBIT/EPS CAGR of 5/7/16%, DCF of valuation of £56 (WACC 7.5%, g=0%) and bull-bear spread of £75-31. We believe our forecasts represent a floor for earnings (Citi -3-6% below pre-Q4 consensus for 2018/19, 2-29% ahead in 2020-22e). Net debt stands at $19bn; despite a pay down schedule exceeding $10bn by 2022 we forecast excess cash flow of $1-6bn per annum, which we channel into buybacks starting 2019. We concede a lack of near term catalysts, over and above the Q1 acceptance of the SHP643 (HAE) filing, but with sentiment at all-time lows we struggle to see significant downside.

MnM Lets hope, am now holding out for £60+
rotorhead Other news overnight from Roche's competitor drug could make you question whether the haemo franchise really is as vulnerable to Roche competition as previously thought. Questions over safety for Roche not going away.
Romeike Shire could easily retrace to £50+ on it's own so a successful deal will need to offer a premium to fair value not just the current share price
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Target £55. And .... well, there's a catalyst now!

Romeike Fair value is around £58 in my view
BE11:24am

Oh, incidentally, it's quite important to stress that Takeda hasn't contacted Shire yet.

BE11:25am

Because Thomas Dittrich, Shire's CFO, bought £303k of shares on the 15th March.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Paid £32.29.

Pharma @BE, interesting, thanks. Pfizer presumably a bit less likely now they've failed to off-load their consumer health unit.
Romeike Pfizer has the clout to make almost whatever acquisition they want at any time
BE11:26am

Anyway, the other rather less important thing re Shire today is Roche .......

BE11:27am

The Hemophilia Federation of America said overnight that five people have died while using Hemlibra

Pharma @Romeike, true. Plus they are deal-addicts.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

(Or emicizumab-kxwh, to give it its non-trade name, which we should do as a matter of course with drugs.)

BE11:28am

We knew one person had died on the HAVEN-1 trial, and there had been other reports in the public domain about possibly unrelated deaths, so it's very hard to read this.

BE11:29am

We don't have any detail whatsoever on precise cause of death

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Also, note that Hemlibra's only approved for the inhibitor population. It's non-inhibitor that's the much bigger market.

GBKrona @pharma - in todays yield hungry world, Pfizer should have lots of strategic options to monetise their consumer helath unit
BE11:30am

Quick bit from Goldman.

BE11:30am

[W]e believe that the safety concerns on Hemlibra will
dominate the discussion and we expect a more moderate penetration for Roche’s Hemlibra here given that patients are well controlled on factor VIII replacements (Shire is the market leader here

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Note that Shire’s inhibitor/non-inhibitor products contributed to 5%/20% of Group sales in 2017, with concerns on the longer-term trajectory of this franchise being a key overhang on the stock. As we highlighted previously, we believe that Shire’s current share price has little contribution being priced in for its Hemophilia franchise. For Roche, contribution from Hemlibra is more moderate with 2023E sales of CHF1.35bn (GSe) or c.2% of Group sales.

Romeike The thing is these companies are currently cash rich and have access to ultra cheap borrowing they can lock in for 10 years + - so now is the time to make strategic aquisitions
GBKrona how on earth do you pronounce emicizumab-kxwh?
BE11:30am

They're on a £46 target, based on 11x 2019E EPS.

VV75 how would Takeda finance a 40+ bid??
Pharma @BE, asking on the basis that you are omniscient; what does the kxwh stand for? Google has not helped.
undefined
Pharma @GBKrona that's partly the point. When it's out of patent GPs will continue to write Heblibra on prescriptions.
Arash Massoudi, FT @BE a bit of intrigue on the M&A advisers here
Pharma *Hemlibra*

11:41 am
BE11:41am

M&A is often seen as a solution, especially in late cycle conditions, although the industry is probably in the early stages of a new cycle. Yet we show how i) balance sheets don’t allow for large all-cash (EPS-enhancing) deals; ii) going down the credit ladder provides little valuation upside (B-rated utilities historically trade on PE premia of just 7% to A-rated ones and that gap has narrowed in recent months); and iii) with network/service/renewable assets trading on ~2x BV for ~11% ROE, EPS uplift pre-Purchase Price Accounting must be greater than 45% for a deal to accrete EPS.

red @Miss Piggyyes cbi report can be hit or miss in relation to official sales but a surprise large fall never a good thing.
BE11:41am

So expect more portfolio restructuring / asset swaps rather than takeovers, says Exane.

red sterling however has taken it reasonably well
BE11:42am

So buy those. Buy the breakup candidates, not the takeover targets.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

The historical correlation between share price performance and two-year forward EPS CAGR is high at greater than 60%, whereas there is no real evidence of equity value uplift from growing company size (market cap to tangible fixed asset ratios have been stagnant or declining). Therefore announced deals should be judged on the potential earnings growth they generate rather than on ‘strategic’ positioning reasons as the former is a better indicator of share price performance.

.... In a sector full of companies struggling in the face of structural
pressures, we believe that Inditex and ABF/Primark stand out as high quality businesses that investors should generally want to own over the long term.

On our analysis, the current ABF share price implies Primark is currently being valued at less than 12x Cal 2019 earnings, versus 20x at Inditex. We see Primark as much less mature, so this seems anomalous to us.

BE11:54am

We conclude that it is ABF that represents the better buying opportunity for those with a c12-month investment horizon. We think profits at Primark are likely to inflect positively in that time frame, whereas we see no sign of the FX headwinds that are hampering Inditex abating.

red per week

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Since Takeda's market cap is close to Shire's we assume a
potential offer would have to include a substantial percentage in equity and how Shire's board and shareholders would react is hard to predict. However as Shire's share price is significantly below the NPV of our cash flow estimates, Takeda could trigger discussion of other bidders.

FATDAZ @Kim well that gigafactory probably eats up quite a lot of cash :)
BE11:58am

.... they were not expecting this, it appears.

Mouselet ah, per week. That is starting to be actually more deliveries than Jaguar.uk
BE11:58am

And were neutral.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Shire does not strike us as an obvious take-over candidate. There is presumably a price at which the financial engineering would work. However, Shire's specialty focus and mix of therapeutic foci means that most buyers would struggle to extract substantial operational synergies while escaping from competition problems, in our view. Also Shire's low corporate tax rate could rise in most scenarios were the company acquired. It would also be a bold acquisition in our view given the uncertain trajectory of Shire's haemophilia business. A merger of equals in this context might be more feasible.

Mouselet kim: They're making factories; indeed they're paying very expensive German factory makers to make them factories
red i actually dont think there is the demand for those cheaper models. thats why they are stalling.
BE11:59am

The argument UBS makes here is that, even if Takeda chooses to walk away, it'll have lit a fire under management's feet.

kim Perhaps they should stick to making (collecting) factories?
red anyone can put up a grand for a deposit but when the final price can hits north of 50 grand with extras, its a diff matter considering that not all of these folks are going to be able to charge on their own terms.
Grouchmonkey @red not that cheap though. Have you seen the price for the Model X?
BE12:00pm

Shire derated because the market doesn't trust its capital allocation policies and, by extension, its board. Can that remain when there's an identified predator circling?

Grouchmonkey Ah you have

Oppenheimer says:

BE12:05pm

We continue to believe that pressure on TSLA’s debt could be amplified in its equity pricing, especially given concerns around delays in reaching profitability. We also believe the increased scrutiny of ADAS programs by regulators along with the NTSB investigation could bring to light any technical issues in TSLA’s system as well as question its implied technical leadership

12:05 pm
BE12:06pm

And Morgan Stanley says:

FATDAZ @here how many other RTA fatalities through driver error were there in the US on the day of the driverless vehicle I wonder
Pseudonym @red In the UK it's Gas and Nuclear before coal.
BE12:06pm

We'd use further weakness from here as an opportunity to build an Equal-weight position in the stock. Tesla is trading at the midpoint between our base case and bear case valuation. We see Tesla as modestly undervalued with very high risk, particularly for investors who are not comfortable with extreme volatility. We continue to expect that Model 3 production bottlenecks will be mitigated, but we do not expect a 5k/week run-rate before deep into the final quarter of 2018. Our discussions with investors suggest expectations for the Model 3 ramp that are clearly below the company's guidance, somewhat de-risking the event path of an official announcement of a further delay.

BE12:07pm

For much of the past seven years, Tesla has nearly monopolized Auto 2.0 amongst the publicly traded OEMS. In our opinion, the next seven years may be a far more volatile and crowded narrative. We rate Tesla Equal-weight with a $379 price target.

FATDAZ sorry lapsing into slack messaging

.... oh, and while I remember, Neil Campling of Mirabaud had some thoughts on the NVidia suspension of Herbies overnight, which might or might not have been the catalyst to the FAANGS selloff.

Puntino @Fatdaz 'if you only have to go in a straight line' was the addendum I had.
Grouchmonkey $379? Hm. I'll make a note of that. Will be v interesting to look back on that prediction in a years' time.
BE12:09pm

Because so much has been made about autonomous vehicle (AV) technology improvements, about how disruptive Nvidia’s own AV technology is, about how the auto OEM’s are already in survival and panic mode because of the massive disruption from the technology advances. Now, probably for the first time, we have to ask the question ; perhaps, the technology doesn’t work? That would have seriously negative implications for the tech complex because much of the recent multiple expansion and “tech Cambrian” (really??) discussions of late have been about the unstoppable rise of AI and its relationship to the biggest application ever (cars), that machine learning will take over the world and every mile of the planet would soon be driven by level 5 autonomous vehicles. Whatever your view of datacentre growth there can be no denying that AV’s and Nvidia’s AV efforts have been a contributing factor behind a stock that has moved from 15x F12M P/E to 45x in three years. The only fair argument for discussion would be about how much it is a factor.

BE12:10pm

"What if it doesn't work" seems to be an under-asked question, I find.

FATDAZ @BE NVidia is at an interesting junction what with chip use in crypto mining and autonomous cars
